title.text: The Man Who Solved the Market

bookmarks.note: Simons went to MIT. He taught at Stony Brook

Renaissance
Medallion
1988 – Summer of 2019
66% before fees
39% after fees
That model of “get the data, and then find correlations it”
“Flip phone”: portrayed as a successful billionaire, Donald Trump uses a flip phone (at least for his campaign communications)
As soon as they started talking about post-renaissance affairs, my interest in the book waned drastically.
Wow, Rebecca Mercer, RenTech CEO’s daughter, controlled the trump campaign.
Feb 15, 2021 — The Quant Quake struck on the week of August 6, 2007. https://thetchblog.com/2021/02/15/quant-quake/

“A wicked man who prosper will bury his children in his lifetime“
Simons is Jewish. He sat shiva, and he continues to live to this day with lots of money but without his son

5B AUM
25% after fees
Sharpe ratio hit 7.5 in 2005

I should do like Simons. Become part of a team; make some place for myself, so that, when I stop seeing things clearly or have to sit out (for a baby or a death, etc.) I am still receiving some income
The Medallion fund’s size was capped at about $5B in 2003
Due to mansions, old field became called the “Renaissance Riviera”
“There’s no data like more data.”

Brown offered to resign after he cost the company hundreds of millions. Simons rejected the offer, saying he was even more valuable now that he had learned never to put his whole faith in a model.

Similar to the story Labkowski said about the guy for whom a company had paid for his master’s(?), and he went to resign after doing something wrong. The story was probably about Brown.

Hell, HSY probably dropped this week (and same with McKesson last week) BECAUSE someone like RenTech’s medallion with hundreds of millions or billions under management is playing this new signal known as “drive the price below the largest call OI and above the largest put OI a few days before OpEx”
Ah, the system had a “problem” in that it ignored recent days’ action. Kind of like how HSY dropped today due to OpEx? No problem, Medallion buys it.
If certain stocks had been going up in recent weeks, Medallion would buy more shares of those stocks. Works great in a bill market, as you accumulate large positions and pyramid on a trend
LTCM’s biggest error: believing its models were truth. Our models don’t reflect reality, they just represent some aspect of reality.
Brown: “any time you hear financial experts talking about how the markets went up because of ‘such and such,’ remember, it’s all nonsense”
Laufer’s strategy was buying at the most propitious days of the week and times of the day
So how would it “self-correct” to get to where it needed to be if, for example, it missed the buy signal to buy gold (like how I said to buy gold at the breakout)

Patterson wanted someone who was smart but miserable in their current job
Why did he want someone who was unhappy?
Lynch -> Fidelity Magellan (1% of Americans owned shares) -> book: One Up on Wall Street
“Know what you own” = Peter Lynch’s investing mantra

Loss aversion: pain = 2x gains
Anchoring: judgment is skewed by initial information/experience
Endowment effect: investors assign extra to things they currently own
1994. The Fed surprised investors with several rate hikes. And Medallion won. So their methods work with (a) surprises, and (b) rate hikes.
But the track record IS the data. You use big data to determine the patterns, the same patterns you would then use backwards to determine a track record
So Shaw, Thorpe, Bezos, and Simons. All the same
Medallion = short-term, not long-term

Ideally, talk to a lot of people. Find out the important news right away. If I found out about Stottler(?) at the end of the cycle, it'd be too late. I can't blame E*TRADE or Robinhood for not being straight with me. They're probably not lying. They just couldn't care less about me, since I don't give them enough money voluntarily.
This is how you win. Don't average down losers. Keep searching for winners.

Interesting. So the Canadian dollar group tried to scam him? Simons stopped trading with them and moved on. Don't focus on the negative. That's averaging down losers. Keep going, keep searching for trends, for the positive.
lol that’s clever

Weekend effect: Monday price action often follows Friday’s
Tuesday often saw reversions to earlier trends

Things I’ve seen happen. Why? Probably because people read this book.
Isn’t this a bit like circular reasoning? We infer the data prior to a date using an algorithm, and then we use that data as inputs to the same algorithm to help predict future data
Kernel methods = name of my idea

Sounds EXACTLY like what I’ve been trying to do. Except I’ve been trying to do it on my own and with $0 in capital. I don’t have any money to fund the machines; I’m relying on my own knowledge to test; and I don’t have any capital to play with even if I’m right
Old AxeComm (division of RennTech) model used basic technical analysis before Carmona
Axe: market like Markov chain
Laufer was the one teasing reversion algos
Do like Baum. Stand too close or memorize the board
Riemann hypothesis
Baum has the same issue I do. Selling. Cut losses cut losses cut losses, and take some profits.
Trivia: Joseph Conrad’s lord Jim + Royal bank of Bermuda
Baum + Simons (together) independently discovered trend following

So I really should do what I thought: get an action potential voltage model.

1) Market sells resemble K+ channels opening.

2) I should also check when in the data and how these mid- to large cap supernovas occur
Simons traded other people’s money, even though he had his own (AND investors’)
Mom says the same things to me
All you need is a mathematical
Probabilistic models for and predictions of stock market behavior

So the IDA is basically just a think tank. I had this thought earlier in the book, but just wrote it down now.
Get a doctorate. Then you get hired for your brainpower, creativity, and ambition. The army hires like this, and so does Google X
Like Neal, Simons learned his material just before teaching the students
PDEs did become very important. In vector algebra, the basis for protein folding, etc

Xeno’s Paradox
1/2s how can you ever reach your destination
Define preternatural
This is what I want. Pay me to do nothing
Uncluttered desk

“Simons was blindsided by most of what took place in his life”
That may be the most important lesson. Be able to embrace and adapt to change quickly. Find the trend as it changes, and follow it until just after everyone realizes (b/c that’s when the biggest short-term gains occur, although these are gambles, but it’s okay because you’re already way in the green on your entry)
